misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the next() method in the Scanner class will read a complete user entry for a student's name, even if that name contains multiple words separated by spaces.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, the Scanner.next() method reads the next token, which is delimited by whitespace. If a user inputs a full name like 'Alice Smith', next() will only capture 'Alice', and 'Smith' will be left in the buffer to be incorrectly assigned to the next student name or cause an InputMismatchException when reading scores.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the input size N (numberOfStudents) will always be at least 1, or that the computer can safely access the index at N-1 regardless of the value of N.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to account for the edge case where N = 0. In Java, if numberOfStudents is 0, the arrays are initialized with a length of 0. Attempting to access studentNames[numberOfStudents - 1] (which evaluates to index -1) will result in a runtime exception.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that since the 'Enter names' prompt is printed once before the loop, the user will (or must) provide all names on a single line of input.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: While the code will technically work if the user provides one name at a time across multiple lines (because Scanner ignores extra whitespace), the student's structure suggests a mental model where the computer's 'request' for data (the prompt) must match the physical layout of the user's 'response'.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that `Scanner.next()` will read an entire name as the user thinks of it (possibly including spaces), i.e., that it captures a whole line/name rather than just the next whitespace-delimited token.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Scanner.next()` stops at whitespace. So if a student name could be something like "Mary Jane" (or if the input formatting differs from the sample), `next()` would read only "Mary" and leave "Jane" to be consumed as the next "name". Reading an entire line requires `nextLine()` (often with care after `nextInt()` due to the leftover newline).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Often produces misaligned inputs (names shift left, scores get read at the wrong time) or unexpected values, especially if names contain spaces or input formatting isn’t exactly one token per name.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that in order to identify and print the maximum value (the 'top student') in a collection, the entire dataset must be rearranged into a sorted order first.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: While sorting works, it is an O(n²) or O(n log n) operation. Finding the maximum value only requires a linear scan O(n) of the array. The student's mental model prioritizes organization of the whole set over efficient targeted retrieval, although in this specific case, the prompt explicitly requested a sort.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Efficiency loss; the program performs far more operations (swapping and comparing) than necessary to answer the specific question of 'who has the highest score'.

evidence.code_snippet: // Step 9: Sort the students by their scores in ascending order

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the next() method will correctly capture a student's full name as a single unit, regardless of whether it contains spaces.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The Java Scanner's next() method is delimiter-based and stops at any whitespace. If a user enters 'Alice Smith', the mental model fails because 'Alice' is stored in the first array index and 'Smith' is stored in the second, shifting all subsequent data out of alignment.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: runtime exception (InputMismatchException) or logic error (names and scores shifted) if names contain spaces.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student understands that the computer does not inherently 'link' the data at index [i] of one array with index [i] of another array, and therefore believes they must manually perform every mutation on both structures to maintain integrity.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: This is actually a correct mental model of Java's notional machine (parallel arrays are independent). However, it highlights a lack of knowledge regarding Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) where a single 'Student' object would naturally encapsulate both properties.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Increased code complexity and maintenance risk; if one swap is forgotten, the data becomes corrupted.
